title: King & Queen Chess Piece Pepper & Salt Mills

description.text:
That's right. A King and Queen chess piece that grinds pepper and salt, for your counter top, to impress your friends.  
Designed to perfectly house a ceramic mechanism from www.CrushGrind.us (Buy the 195 mm mechanism).

Print with 20% infill, 2 shells, 0.20 mm  
Clean up the supports.  
If you like a smoother finish (like I did for the ones in teh picture), put them in an acetone fume bath for 20 minutes each. Let them harden again for at least an hour before touching.  
Install the mechanism into the base. You'll have to press one of the 2 expansion tongs so it slides in. Keep pressing in until it clicks into place.  
Cut the shaft that extends out the top, so that you leave exactly 30 mm.  
Push the white "top fit" into the base of the top, until it clicks.  
Fill with peppercorns, or salt (even rock salt).  
Slide the top into the shaft.  
Grind.  
Push your jaw back up with your hand to close your mouth.

This is the Nano Urgent Response System. It was a project for school that had to use a Sparkfun Redboard to use three sensor inputs to process information for any situation in a third-world country. My group chose to measure some simple vital signs: pulse, pulse oximetry, and temperature. I designed this case to house the project and a tray insert to hold the LCD screen for the info, guide the wires, and hide the board. I had to print the element that held the lights and sensors for the pulse oximeter as well. The lid closes well and holds all the elements with two magnets to latch it. The hinge is made so that I could use some PLA filament and heat it up so that it straightens. Then I cut the length and used a soldering iron to melt the ends into a flat nail head shape.

I measured the dimensions of the board and estimated the volume needed to hold the elements and the wires. I then created a box and tray to house them all in Inventor. The hinge is made so that I could use some PLA filament and heat it up so that it straightens. Then I cut the length and used a soldering iron to melt the ends into a flat nail head shape.

I bought a daylight/UV lamp for my aquarium, but the tank has a lip for a hood, and the lamp clamp was made for a tank without a lip, so I made this adapter the hold my light, and it has been lighting my tank for about 6 months now. I also made it out of glow in the dark PLA because it looks great in UV light.

I measured the dimensions of the tank and made it where it would sit on the lip, then added holes for M5 x 16mm screws to hold it onto the tank. It ended up being snug enough to not need the screws, but I put them on just in case. I also added a slot so that the power cord would not be obstructed.

Aim: Make an easy and fast hotend not needing any special tools. Result: As of now, do not build this hotend, or use other resistors, I already fried two.. so back to brainstorming mode! In the final steps of finishing a RepRap Mendel, I was fideling with the Extruder Hot End. Unable to get a nice working and easy to connect Nichrome wire heater, I switched to power-resistor usage and found myself with the big question of how to attach it to the nozzle. Found the following: Attach the rectangular 6R8 5W resistor (with ceramic casing) with... Copper Wire to the nozzle. Add lots of heat conducting paste. Build a heat shield with... Capton Tape, several layers of it, folded onto a square copper wire frame to give more stability. Add a 5 Cent Euro piece (copper) to the bottom to fix it all, with one threaded 6mm hole for the nozzle, and one 2mm hole for the thermistor. Connected to 12V Power Source, Manual Extrusion works flawlessly already (and without burning my fingers holding the PEEK insulator). More on this design as soon as I have been using it for some prints. Will probably also add capton tape to the bottom side of the printed Wade's extruder for thermic insulation. Improvement suggestions are welcome. Video of 1st test run on extruder: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SdaGdV4FYUY Video of 2nd test run (high speed): http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nI6yL4VfNfo The test rig is an arduino piloting a pololu at a speed set by the variable resistor.

title: RaspberryPi Cam NoIR with IR-LEDs mount for Rigidbot

description.text:
A mount for a RaspberryPi Cam NoIR with IR-LEDs from Ebay,
designed to fit a Rigidbot, that will follow the X-carriage up and down while printing. The arm is hollow to allow for the video-cable and LED power-cable to go through it and then through the metal bar the rods are attached to.
(I will then eventually mount a cable chain on the other side that will carry the cables) (Note, All pictures is from a previous version of the mount, all part have been slightly altered to make it work better.)

Caution. Cura doesn't do very well on internal dimensions when slicing for the Rigidbot. I recommend a different slicer for parts that need to fit in each other. I used a friends Simplify3d to slice all parts. The arm should be printed standing up with the rounded side down.
(I printed the arm with 2 different settings in one go with simplify 3d, processettings is included with the files.) The ball needs to sanded down a bit on the underside as it is hard to print a perfect sphere. But getting it to pop in place in the arm should still be hard so its not to loose when in place. Getting the cable through the metal bar is kinda tricky but possible.
The lower side screws for the x-motor and the holders for the rods (part 1002) needs to be removed. the video-cable and the power-cable needs to be on different side of the rods to be able to get the holders back in place afterwards. (Note, All pictures is from a previous version of the mount, all parts have been slightly altered to make it work better.)

comments.text: Tried with Cura and indeed the pins won't fit the holes and the cover is kind of tight. Also. the flat cable of the RaspiCam NoIR is not log enough for this, I'll have to keep the RasPI in the nearest corner or maybe even attach it to the gantry itself. Those are the issues of theshort flat cable,but I knew that from the get-go.

Quickly fills, then levels out, measuring cups. An approximate 1 cup measure is supplied as an example, designed for this creation. Good for kernels, seeds, flour, sugar, anything in large quantities but small bits. A funnel, lock(to allow controlled flow), and the base are given. When the handle lines up with the ridge on the funnel, it is completely open. When it is perpendicular, it is fully shut. Prints in 4 parts, in 3 files, on a Replicator 5th Gen. No extra parts are required.

The assembly is quite intuitive. Put the measure on the base in the slot, and put the funnel with the ingredient over the measure. The funnel should fit into the base quite snugly in the hollowed out section. There should be only a small amount of space between the measure and the funnel.  
Note: Though this may seem obvious, put the lock&handle in BEFORE the substance. You will have a gigantic mess otherwise.  
Cleanup: Wiping down the base and measure with a damp sponge should work just fine. The same goes for the funnel and lock.

If you hate it when you set your sponge down when you are washing the dishes and it drips all over the counter, you may want to consider printing this out.  
I have designed it with a mindful draining system so that when you are finished doing the dishes you can make sure that the sponge dries also preventing the risk of your sponge going moldy. There is a tasteful design on the holder making your kitchen look that little bit better. You can easily remove the supports with a drill. I have made it with an indent in the front/back (depends on the way you position it) so it will be simple to pick up.   
This design is very versatile if will fit almost any double sink. You can adjust it after is has been printed.  
I hope helps make your life that little bit easier!

You can easily install this sponge holder once it has been printed. You will need:
2, 3 mm bolts
2, 3 mm nuts All you do is slide the bolt through the plate and into the holder.
Then tighten up the nut. When printing you should not have any problem with the print sticking but if you do you can rotate sponge holder piece 1 onto it's side and drill it out after.

description.text:
Have you ever groped for a knife, grabbing several before finding the one you want? Have you ever considered how clean you knife block truly is? And have you ever gotten annoyed at how heavy and large your knife block is, and how it gets in the way, taking up precious space? No longer, as this is a fully washable knife rack with a clear view of all your knives. This rack can stand up, taking up very little counter space, even leaning forward slightly, mount on a wall or even under a cabinet. Things could be hung from the bottom when mounted like that, but nothing has yet been designed.  
It can hold 6 knives, four 27-millimeter wide knives and two 37-millimeter wide knives. The knives can be as thick as 3 millimeters, so it is better for thinner, less sturdy knives, such as bread knives or smaller knives, rather than thicker knives, such as the largest knives in the sets. However, when mounted under a cabinet, more knives or other things can be placed on top of it, forming a sort of shelf. It can be washed with relative ease, while it is even easier to decide when to wash it. The Dual lock, which the link to is in the instructions, is resilient, and will allow the rack to be moved around to different locations, without wearing out like double-sided tape.  
Print it out, and never grumble about your knife block again!

Print
DO NOT USE SUPPORTS. In the pictures, some roughness can be seen. These are from supports. Most come off easily, but certain parts are nearly impossible to remove. I even used a rotary tool in the sides. If can print soluble supports, go right ahead. But otherwise, stay clear of the supports. I designed it to bridge, and I have seen the same printer bridge further.
Remove supports and raft(if any)
This is not strictly necessary, but will make the design more aesthetically pleasing, and easier to clean.
Attach Dual Lock
This is the link:
http://solutions.3m.com/wps/portal/3M/en_US/Adhesives/Tapes/Products/~/3M-Dual-Lock-Reclosable-Fastener-SJ3870?N=5927706+3294281433&rt=rud When you buy these, get the 1/2 inch(12mm). They can be as wide as 18 millimeters, but after that, they will be wider than the rear supports. Put a set on the rack on the wide sections, and put some on the wall or under a cupboard with the SAME spacing. These will allow you to put the rack where you want it, and allow you to pop it off and move it. After that, nothing is required!

comments.text: As soon as I saw this upload I knew I had to print it. I've wanted a beanbag basketball my whole life, and with this file and my new three dimensional printer, it was now possible. I wanted this to be amazing so bad; I really got my hopes up. You know how they say never meet your heroes because you imagine they are better than they actually are and you'll just be let down? Well the same could be said for this beanbag basketball. I spent almost 12 hours printing this and a ton of plastic. I had dreams of sitting on this, sinking in, and falling right to sleep in comfort. When the printer told me it was done, I rejoiced. I waited an hour for it to cool and took it out. I placed it on the floor, and like jumping into a pool for the first time, I closed my eyes, held my breath and took a dive down into the beanbag basketball. My disappointment rushed over my body like the swimming pool temperature was just above freezing; the shock was unbearable. It was not the soft, bosom loving beanbag basketball that I once dreamed of. Shattered dreams, disappointment, despair. Take my pain as a lesson so you don't have to go through what I did. Not everything is what it seems. Print at your own risk. P.S. Doesn't make a good basketball either.

description.text:
The breaker is a small intelligent guy. He supports himself with arms
and legs inside a plastic globe. Because of the ball, he can do a lot
of different moves. Underneath his cap he has a lot of weight to keep
him balanced all the time. In addition, without the globe he performs
well on his arms and legs.

Print the little guy! The best material would be a flexible one,
because that way you can twist him into the ball and get a lot more
'moves' done. The cheaper version, of course, is to go with a hard
plaster printer. I colored him afterward. It took me several hours...
color printing wouldn't be a bad idea either. ;) To save material it
would be best to give him a smaller material thickness. i just made a
rough 'hole' inside his body. Have fun breakdancing!

author: fisign

description.text: This is a bracket that positions a 40mm diameter cooling fan over the Pololu A4983 stepper drivers in the RAMPS (RepRap Arduino Mega Pololu Shield). The fan used was a 40X40X20 12VDC FAN, RS Stock No. 544-0526 http://uk.rs-online.com/web/search/searchBrowseAction.html?method=searchProducts&searchTerm=544-0526&x=25&y=8 The fan is countersunk into the bracket and fixed in place by M3x30 socket screws. Additional holes in the corners of the bracket line up with the mounting holes in the shield board. M3 stud, coated in PTFE tube (d3D4.5) to prevent any shorts, was used to position the bracket above the shield. The fan can plug into the 12VIN and GND-IN pins just beneath D8 on the shield.

Print the bracket and clean out the holes using an M3 drill bit.
Countersink the fan into the bracket and bolt into place using washers to prevent damage to fan and bracket.
Cut M3 stud and PTFE tube to required length, allowing enough space for RAMPS wiring - I used 55mm length for the PTFE tube, 70mm for M3 stud.
Tighten a nylock M3 nut onto the end of each of the M3 studs, place through the shield, slot the PTFE tube over, washers, bracket, washers and finally plain nut.*
Connect the fan red wire into the 12VIN pin and the black wire in the GND-IN pin on the shield, just next to D8.
*Purpose of plain nut on top and nylock on bottom is so top plain nut can be tightened and the stud won't push through the bottom nylock into the Arduino Mega below.

title: Solution for printing with water soluble PVA in Dualstrusion

description.text:
How to use PVA without it absorbing ambient moisture.
The filament is to be contained in a airtight connector that only exposes the filament to ambient moisture for a few seconds before it is extruded. More information at: http://robosavvy.com/forum/viewtopic.php?p=37534#37534

comments.text: I've got this fully printed, and picked up a container, which isn't perfectly sealed. However, I also went out and picked up a gun safe heater (like 10w), and have a thermal controller ($20 for the controller).  So I'm going to set it up as a thermal controlled unit.  I'll upload pics shortly. And plan to put some desiccants in the box as well.
comments.author: guitartoys

comments.text: Awesome.
comments.author: EricYoung

comments.text: How well does it keep water out?   Have you put a humidity gauge inside the box.   Water vapor is one hellova difficult thing to fight against.  My job deals with water vapor, and I can pretty much assure you that after a few hours your box's humidity will be equal to the outside humidity.   Dessicant is absolutely useless as long as the container is not hermetically sealed or under  positive pressure with a dry gas.  Please dont think I am needlessly bashing your Idea.  There is a big difference between this looks like it keeps water out, and this solution keeps water out.
comments.author: sciencemike

comments.text:
Hi sciencemike. Good to get some feed back from an expert.
Of course this system is only as good as the original container, how well you seal the spout with hot glue and the snug fit of the filament on the latex.
We do not have a humidity gauge, but what i can say is that usually a few hours exposed to atmosphere is enough for PVA to become softer, and harder to extrude.
I have a roll in this system for over a week now and it is still bone dry.
I assume whatever small leakage there is, is small enough for the desiccant bags inside to maintain a dry atmosphere.
Anyone who buys filament should have a steady supply of desiccant bags to reuse (just as long as they are stored in a airtight container so avoid becoming saturated with ambient moisture).
However we might have a need for a more professional system based on this so I will get a humidity gauge to do a more scientific approach.
comments.author: sciencemike

comments.text: I think sciencemike's solution should work just fine concerning the small leakage.  He putted some desiccant packages in the container to remove moisture actively.

author: AwesomeA

description.text: This stylish scale (if I do say so myself) can't be beat for simplicity - it's really just a lever and a rolling fulcrum.  Just push it left or right on the roller until it tips, and then the roller position marks the weight.

Update: I've updated the paper gauge with a slightly more accurate version.  
You'll need 50 pennies, two O-rings (1/8" thick by 3/4" ID), and two 6-32 x 1/4"L socket cap screws.  I printed the beam, roller, tray and penny bin in PLA with 0.2mm layers, 3 perimeters, and 20% infill.  You'll need supports turned on for the beam (which prints on its side), but they break away really easily.  To assemble, first insert the roller by flexing the retaining strap on the bottom side of the beam so the roller will fit through.  Next stretch the O-ring tires onto either side of the roller.  Screw the penny bin onto one side of the beam with one of the 6-32 screws.  Screw the other 6-32 screw directly into the hole on the opposite side.  (The tray has an indentation in the bottom that sits on top of the screw head.)  Print the paper gauge strip and attach it to the front beveled edge of the beam with double-sided tape.  Finally, put 13 pennies each in two opposing penny slots and and 12 pennies each in the other two opposing penny slots.  
To use the scale, put what you want to weigh in the center of the tray (things placed off-center won't be weighted as accurately) and place the tray on the end of the beam.  Make sure the scale is on a flat, smooth surface (like a countertop!).  Push the entire scale left or right until it tips on the roller. The position of the center of the roller on the gauge strip will indicate the weight.  
The gauge strip is calibrated for 50 pennies.  If you want a more accurate scale for lighter amounts, you can remove some of the pennies and print a new gauge strip for the opposite side of the scale.  (You can use your leftover pennies to calibrate the new gauge - each penny weighs 2.5 grams.)

description.text: This system works by combined rows of hexagons in whatever color, shape, size, and pattern you want. The inside dimensions are 1in by 2in deep so by scaling you can fit whatever size or shape container you want. The tabs on the bake allow the layers to be staked without sliding off. The hexagons are at a 10 degree angle so the containers slide to the back. Some ideas for full models are a pyramid, square, or large hexagon.

• scale to size

    3.print one of each needed
  • stack on top of each outer
    5.fill

Print out one of each file. When printing the "bristles" file, stop the print after the first layer. After you have collected the bristles off of the build plate, cut them down to size and then connect them together. The easiest way I found to do this is to melt the ends of the bristles together with a soldering iron. After you have your bristles created, place them within the brush. Again, I used a soldering iron to sort of "weld" the bristles to the brush. I also added super glue to ensure that the bristles would stay in place. Finally, I closed the two brush halves together. This is designed to be a tight fit and may require some slight sanding. If you would like to add a magnet to your dust pan, it is designed to hold a 3/8" x 3/8" round magnet like this one (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000TKH2W0/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1)

description.header: Blobby protection made by the masses
description.text:
Blob is an easy to assemble zipper pouch made to carry small things like change, a small mp3 player or your favorite headphones. The triangular domed shape is highly protective, and the guide holes make it extremely easy to stitch on a common 10" zipper to complete the project.  
The object has been designed with snap-off supports that help keep Blob well attached to your print bed throughout the print process.

Blob is a design collaboration between Carla García and Juan Noguera, two Providence, Rhode Island based makers and designers who enjoy putting things into cases. We truly hope you like having these guys around as much as we do.
print two pieces. you can mix and match colors to make some interesting blobs. I used two shells and a 40% infill.
Snap off the support pads on the button that help adhere blob to your print bed.

Using carpet / button thread (for resistance) and a common household needle, stitch one side of the zipper around one of the shells. repeat on the other side. When complete, you can seal the joint with additional thread to reinforce the "hinge".

This is my Counter-top Herb Garden It has three removable pots, a drip tray and a height adjustable light.  I've got mine plugged into a timer to keep the light on the right amount of time every day.  
It's designed to print without any supports.  The slopes on the inside of the pots and in the mid support of the base are fairly aggressive but don't worry if you get a few dangling pieces of plastic there you won't be able to seem them once it's all put together.  
I printed everything with 2 shells and 10% infill.  Make sure you use at least two shells on the drip tray so it doesn't leak.  
Everything should click together fairly firmly, but I recommend glueing the back bar into place once you've test fit everything.  
Fresh herbs make all the difference in cooking.

You'll need to print out two side pots and one of everything else.  
Assembly  
Everything should snap together fairly firmly but you may want to glue to back bar for extra stability.  I use methylene chloride to join PLA parts, it works like Acetone with ABS dissolving the plastics and then evaporating allowing them to become one piece.  If you decide to use Methylene Chloride wear gloves and avoid breathing it in.  
Covering the inside of the hood  
To finish off the hood cover the inside with Aluminum tape.  This is NOT the same as Duct tape, you should be able to find it at your local hardware store.  It's sort of a pain to work with but the adhesive is good up to over 100C and it is reflective so it will reflect the light back down to your plants.  Cover all the internal surfaces except the inside of the area meant to hold the lamp socket.  Aluminum tape is conductive and you wouldn't want it shorting your wiring.  
Wiring  
I cut the end off an old extension cord to use as the wire you'll want to put a lamp rod nut over the end of your wire, then run the wire through the hole at the top of the hood through the lamp rod and connect it to your lamp socket.  Use the shortest lamp socket you can find where the power is wired to the bottom of the socket.  I bought mine at Home Depot.  Once everything is wired together with your lamp rod attached to your socket screw the lamp rod through the hole at the top of your hood as far as it will go and secure it with the lamp rod nut.  
Lighting  
I used a 24W Compact florescent bulb which puts out light equivalent to a 100W incandescent bulb.  It's probably a bit overkill.  
WARNING!! never  use an incandescent bulb, or any bulb greater than 24W in your herb garden.  
Grow!  
Plant some seeds and watch them grow.  You can poor water into your herb garden pots without moving them.  When you're done pull out the drip tray and dump out the run off.  
Happy Growing!

description.text: Virtox's Julia Vase series is one of my favorite things in the whole wide Thingiverse. He never published his workflow so I set out to reverse engineer my own version. After all, how hard could it be to voxel stack a non-linear perturbation of a Julia set? It is actually quite easy and I posted a video at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8VmPtCf8m34 so anyone can explore these amazing forms. If you try it be sure to post what you come up with and comment any problems you have and any improvements you make to the technique. The stl is a solid. To print it as a hollow vase just slice without a top or infill. This usually works better than a baked in wall thickness. We talked about this on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, Stitcher radio or direct from the source at http://threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com/

description.text: While playing with my version of Virtox's Julia Vase technique I stumbled upon some amazingly chaotic variations. Empowered with an utter ignorance of the math involved I modeled a perturbation of the power factor of a Mandelbrot set. The result is so different from the Julia Vases that it is hard to believe they were generated the same way. I printed it, but with all the overhangs and gorgeous fragile fine details, the print doesn't really do it justice. I posted a tutorial video at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8VmPtCf8m34 so anyone can explore these amazing forms. If you try it be sure to post what you come up with and comment any problems you have and any improvements you make to the technique. Virtox's Julia Vase series is one of my favorite things in the whole wide Thingiverse. He never published his workflow so I set out to reverse engineer my own version. After all, how hard could it be to voxel stack a non-linear perturbation of a Julia set? It is actually quite easy and I posted a video at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8VmPtCf8m34 so anyone can explore these amazing forms. If you try it be sure to post what you come up with and comment any problems you have and any improvements you make to the technique. The stl is a solid. To print it as a hollow vase just slice without a top or infill. This usually works better than a baked in wall thickness. We talked about this on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, Stitcher radio or direct from the source at http://threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com/

description.text:
Here is a clamp that fits perfectly onto a cabinet where one can hang numerous things using the multiple attachments that snap into place with the Long, Medium, or Short adapters. These attachments are swappable making it very customizable and personal for its specific use.   
So far there are 4 possible attachments: The Small Container, The Large Container (Assembled using the 2 Parts), The paper towel/roll holder, and the Hanging Utensil Rack. All of the attachments are swappable with the different sized Adapters. The Clamp allows one to create unlimited amounts of attachments that snap onto the Adapter allowing for anyone to create an attachment that can be used for there needs. This allows the clamp and adapters to be used in many different ways. For example, the paper towel attachment can be also used for aluminum foil, or saran wrap, or any other type of Roll that is similar in shape.   
There are endless possibilities with how one can use the attachments, and the number of attachments one can create. More attachments are on the way!! Coming soon: iPad Holder Attachment, Multifunction Containers, and much more.  
This project took lots of revising to allow for the clamps to be strong enough to handle the excess weight from the Adapters and the attachments with their functions, yet flexible enough to easily be removed and clamped again at a different location perhaps. These clamps are perfect for people who do not want to drill any holes or glue things permanently to there cabinets or walls.   
The Adapters are strong, and easy to snap into and out of the attachments, allowing for many different possibilities for the types of attachments to be used.   
Each Attachment has been revised to allow for the greatest versatility, easily adjustable with the adapters.  
An endless number of combinations can be created, allowing for these individual parts to come together and make the best of the empty space between the Countertops and the Cabinets.

All of these individual parts were created to fit perfectly with each other. Look at the images provided to get a better understanding of how the attachments snap into place with the adapters. It's a fairly simple design with multiple uses. Each Print was done within the following parameters:
Print Quality: Low (To allow for faster prints)
Layer Height: .3mm
Perimeters Minimum: 2
Fill Density: 50% (To allow the best combination of Strength and Flexibility
No Need of the Following: Skirts and Brim, Support Materials
Filament Used: PLA
Infill Type: Grid All of these individual parts were printed using a ROBO 3D R1 Small Container Dimensions: 4in X 8in
Large Container Dimensions when assembled: 6in X 14in
Long Adapter Dimensions: 6in
Medium Adapter Dimensions: 4.5in
Short Adapter Dimensions: 3in
Hanging Utensil Rack Dimensions: 3in X 8in
Clamp Dimensions: 8.5in

title: Hold Down / Clamps for Desktop Milling Machine / Shapeoko / xCarve

description.text:
Another mix of the standard Milling Machine hold downs. I wasn't happy with the performance or design of the others, and the lack of source files to customize always annoys me... so, I drafted up a set in Inventor 2014. These are setup to work with 5mm bolts but you can customize the source files as needed (or scale your STL along the width axis to elongate the 5.5mm opening for the clamp bolt. If you scale the length, you'll need to scale all of the parts correspondingly or the mating surface between the step blocks and the hold down bars won't align anymore tho!  
Update: I changed the hold down bar to remove the bevel from the top side. This allows for easier printing (print the bars "upside down" with the teeth facing up) without a need of support or fear of warping during the print if printed without.

Print Settings:
When printing the parts initially, I printed them at a high percentage of infill for strength. I believe my initial prints were done with a 60% infill w/rectilinear fill pattern. This lends itself to being very strong for clamping and does a good job at resisting cracking or delamination of the print while in use, but at the cost of using a LOT of filament for an otherwise small part. So, after printing a bunch more and tested each, I'm changing my recommendation on print settings. I now find, for myself at least, that the means for these to be strong, yet light and print quickly, is using a higher perimeter count... Going with something closer to 10 or 15 gives you some solid shell for the connection points, which will remain rugged after lots of use, yet only require something like a 20% infill and a 200 micron layer heights. For print settings for the Arms I most frequently print them with 8-10 perimeters, and 6-8 solid layers for top/bottom. With all that, then going with 20% infill is all that's needed really, as the infill at that point is just providing mass vs strength of the part.You do need enough infill for when you are clamping down, especially if you don't have a large washer to distribute the load, to prevent the clamp arm from being potentially crushed if you have to really crank down on a part.

Print Orientation:
For the actual printing orientation on the print platform, I have been most successful by orienting them as such:
  • Steps - Print on the side, with the teeth facing sideways. I find it's best to print these in pairs with the teeth facing each other, with the part oriented 180 degrees to one another, such that the pair then forms a large rectangle with the space between the two. Give yourself about 4-6mm between them, which should allow your slicer to lay down some brim that bridges between the two parts for your first layer.
  • Bars - Print on back, with teeth facing UP.

Use:
There is a reason for this design for clamps having been used for 200+ years... but you DO have to use them correctly... and that method MAY not be completely obvious. If your bars are bending under clamping force, you are clamping too far away from the work. Remember, when clamping parts, especially for milling, clamp with the bolt as close to the work as you can get it. Don't clamp in the middle or further away, or you will 1) put a lot of stress on the clamping bar and 2) you get MUCH less clamping force. That's just plain ol' leverage/physics! I see photos online ALL the time of people clamping things just terribly wrong on their desktop milling machines (and even full sized Bridgeport Mills) where you can see their clamps bending in the middle from the bolt in the wrong location, and people using the step blocks at the wrong heights (level or too low typically, tho sometimes too high also) so very frequently... and it's just because they were not taught how to use the clamps correctly. Hopefully this helps if you didn't previously know. :) The point is to clamp JUST slightly above down onto the part. The flat of the clamping bar should NOT be flat against the part. What you are doing is trying to clamp with just the edge where the flat transitions to the bevel. This translates the maximum force to a single point, holding it down. With plastic printed parts, we are limited by the strength of our material... but with metal clamps, you can generate TONS (not exaggerating) of force with very little amounts of clamping force. This is why the end of the bars are beveled... to make the bottom of that "V" of the clamp has a small surface area. As I said, this may not be obvious at first, especially to someone who hasn't been trained in machining and are just figuring it out as they go along... but if you consider the physics (google Clamping with Inclined Plane and/or Coefficient of Friction if you are REALLY interested in all this) you'll quickly see where and how to use this style of step block clamp and why it's pretty much THE method utilized by machinist first and foremost whenever they can. So... Set the bar such that there is a slight decline from the high end of the steps down to the part being clamped. You want the clamping bar to be set 1 or possibly 2 steps (no more) above the surface of your part / stock... so the bar should NOT be level, and it should only have the corner of the clamping bar contacting the material, not more (aka a flat from the bars main body, or the flat of the bevel of the end of the bar... and the bar should never be level or lower than your material! This is why there are SO many teeth on the step block, so you can get JUST the right angle for clamping. Also, always use the shortest clamping bar you can. Remember, when machining, it's ALL about rigidity Rigidity RIGIDITY! Sometimes you have to use a longer bar, especially with the SO2 where your clamping points are somewhat limited in their spacing (lacking T-Nuts with the ability to position almost anywhere) but just use the shortest clamping bar you can, and put your clamping bolt as close to the work as you can manage.

comments.text: The hold downs are held in place with the bolt screwing down into the threaded inserts. If you aren't using threaded inserts in your wasteboard, then ANY form of holddown is going to be problematic for you. These hold downs are just a basic version of the standard type of holddowns that are used on milling machines. Those are usually steel... which could prove to be catastrophic with a Shapeoko if the cutter moved into the holddown. With 3D printed plastic holddowns, even if you graze the holddown, all that happens is you buzz the plastic a bit... and you can just print another. Well... assuming you have (or have access to) a 3D printer... which if you are looking at these, the assumption is that you likely do. :)

comments.text: this was done deliberately as I was getting lots of messages from people having problems printing the part. By inverting the bevel part I also basically force people into using the clamps "correctly" by creating a V point to concentrate clamping pressure. With using printed plastic parts, and by folks not trained as machinists, sometimes ya just gotta give them every helping edge you can. Yes, it means the strap clamp hangs over the work a bit more than it might need to. I left that as an unfortunate tradeoff, but one I felt worth it. Plus, it gives the clamp a little more strength to tolerate the heavy clamping forces.

description.text:
In need of nutrition information for your large eggs?  Then this drawing is just what you've been looking for! 
This is a 3200 x 800 pixel plot intended for plotting with the Eggbot.
P.S. The text was rendered using the new Hershey Text extension by Windell Oskay and distributed with the latest Eggbot software release.  It may be found in Inkscape under Extensions > Render > Hershey Text (after you update to the latest Eggbot software).  The utility of that extension is not limited to just the Eggbot.  Among other things, it provides nice, non-filled, single stroke fonts ideal for use in CNC and CNC-related applications.

The file nutrition.svg is the original artwork.  When plotted on chicken eggs or ping pong balls, the text may be a bit too tiny.  Hence the existence of nutrition2.svg which has had the text "Not a significant source of dietary Fiber or Sugar" removed and the remaining text enlarged somewhat.  And, obviously, it's been rotated 180 degrees for plotting with the fat end of the egg at the Eggbot's headstock, and the Eggbot's user contributed "stretch" extension applied.
Each SVG file has two layers:
1 - test -- this is a framing layer which you can plot (with or without a pen) to ensure that you have the pen's starting position where you want it. Plot this using the "Layers" tab of the Eggbot Control extension and select "1" for the layer. A short tick mark at y=800 and another at y=0 will be drawn.
2 - drawing -- this is the actual drawing.
The plot shown in the image was done with a fairly fine tipped pen -- a 0.05mm Copic Multiliner SP.  For that particular egg and the arm height setup I had at the time I plotted, I found it helpful to tip the ends up on the Eggbot when plotting at the extreme edges.  That to get good pen tip contact: my fine tipped Multiliner SPs can sometimes be touchy when writing at angles far from vertical.

title: Ice / Chocolate mold raspberry with leaves sketchup meshmixer tutorial
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Ice / Chocolate mold raspberry with leaves tutorial
for making a raspberry ice cake.
Don't forget 2 vote @
http://www.instructables.com/id/Raspberry-Ice-Pie-W-3DPrinting/

Raspberry ice cake Needed
Free software,
this instructable
A 3D printer or 3D Printing service
icecream
raspberry jam
2-3kiwi's
whipped cream
a spatel
a handmixer
a freezer Download
sketchup make. http://www.sketchup.com/download
Autodesk meshmixer. http://www.meshmixer.com/download.html download "3d animation -blackberry, raspberry, rubus" from User "Rubus" on googles 3d warehouse by searching "raspberry"
https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com
https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model.html?id=3252bc65933665184e08fc4ea39c13e7 open in sketchup, &
download stl plugin from googles extention warehouse via "window" in the menu in your sketchup program.
then export as stl repair this stl @ https://netfabb.azurewebsites.net/ download vine leaf right by miodragd (but my repaired edition) @thingiverse http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:714034 open the repaired "raspberry" model in meshmixer
then click "import"
it will ask wether to "append" , "replace" or "cancel".
Choose "append"
go to your repaired "vine leaf" stl, and click "open".
Meshmixer will ask wether or not to repair the new models larger faces. choose yes. Now the models are in meshmixer, you need to know how to navigate. use youtube tutorials for better explanation then mine;
click and hold right mouse bttn = look around(move the camera)
pressing "c" centers the screen to the point of your cursor at that moment.
zoom with your mouse wheel scroller. more knowledge is for later. lets go with this first.
if you don't see a small window called "object browser", go to menu "Vieuw" and click "show object browser".
you can see in that object browser your two imported models.
ignore the magnet symbol behind your model name, click the eye on and off, just too see what it does. its handy for later. Now resize your Vine Leaf until propper size by
selecting it in your object browser
clicking on "edit" (left) wich makes a new menu appear.
in that new menu, choose "transform".
Now, for each axes, you get a straight arrow, wich moves the model along that axes.
and a bend colored piece, wich makes you tilt your model on that axes. just click, hold, and drag.
@the end of the axes indicator there is a square appendix, wich is used too stretch the model on that specific axle. @the center of the arrows, there is a small white box. click, hold and drag up or down to scale your model.
test some, and ctrl-z ;) These are the basic navigation you need to complete this instructable, for further tutorials, please refer too a search engine :D So scale your leaf, drag it into position, rotate it till its cosy, and click accept.
Now select that leaf in object browser, and Mirror it by clicking "edit" and "mirror"
meshmixer will give you a plane to pull in order to define the mirroring point in relation to the original object.
if u pull it far enough, a new , mirrored object will appear next to it.
also edit transform and drag this mirrored leaf in place. now select all objects in your objects browser, and click "combine" in the new appearing, small window.
your objecs are now one object. Allmost there...
Go to "edit" and choose "plane cut".
meshmixer will supply a plane wich you can move with the navigation arrows until they JUST touch the leaves you meshmixed onto them.
Make the cut when your satisfied.
do not select "no fill" when you click accept. both other options will do. Go to "analasys" and select "flat fill" and "auto repair all" Now your raspberry is ready for 3D Printing.
But we want a mold ;)
i know you looked high and low, so here it is; first thing you need is a form wich can be used to hollow your model out(substract it off-make negative-etc)
i suggest you go to "meshmix"-"primitives" and "append" a cube. now scale, stretch, and drag the cube on top of your raspberry for measuring,
stretch till the whole half :p raspberry fits in it, then pull it out until it Nearly sticks out of the cube. select one model at the time in the object browser, go to "edit" and select make solid one by one.
for your imported raspberry , select "accurate" in the drop-down menu, and play with the rest until you are content with the surface. then accept.
for the cube, do the same, but use standard values, and accept. select your Raspberry(solid) in the object browser, press and hold ctrl, and then select your cube(solid)
you can unvieuw the meshes by clicking the "eye" icon next to your model names in the object browser for more clarity. now choose"edit" and then "boolean diffrence"
if the wrong side appears, ctrl-z, & try changing the sequence of selecting Solids (first raspberry, then box)
if the result aint wanted, ctrl z, or click "decline"
and "transform" your cube or rasberry up and down until it works,
if it still doesnt, try rotating the raspberry 45° according to the box.
you should get a result similar to this:
pic now your solid is just one model. you can now "cut planes" again to reduce material use in printing. "analyze" and "fix all" And before exporting, we are going to "reduce" the number of faces by going via "select",
selecting any part in the model by clicking on the model
and going via "edit"in the newly appeared menu, too "reduce"
in this case, you want to select "triangle budget", research the rest ;)
keep the second drop-down-menu on "shape preserving"
and click the "tri count" slider back until one fourth (1/4) of the slider.
make sure "preserve boundries" is checked and
accept. your filesize just went from +/-80.000kb to +/-7.000kb,
wich is about the max filesize you can comfortably load on a windows pc running repetier with less then 4GB Ram memory
now click "export" (left) 3D Print the mold, preferably in someting flexible or soluble, something hard wont work because of the raspberries form,
the model will not come out of a PLA or ABS hard material form. just the way it is with the raspberry i made.
you could "remesh" the raspberry before the "boolean diffrence" to smoothen the surface and fix this.
i won't, my girl just asked me if she had to "buzz like a pc too" in order for me too come to bed... just, Print the model, or have it printed online or locally via 3D hubs or your local 3D printing store, take 1L icecream take 300gr red colored jam take 3 kiwi's and squash them, mix(spatel/handmixer) jam with the 4/5 icecream and a coffecup of whipped cream
mix(spatel/handmixer) kiwijuice with the 1/5 leftover icecream and good dot of whipped cream
leave the icream in the freezer until everything is prepared Spatel the two color mixes in the mold, and put back in the freezer. Enjoy!

description.text:
This is a fairly large Cryptex, which is a personal storage vault for valuable items or documents based on a concept described in The Davinci Code. This particular design is easily picked and so it is more appropriate for fun than the actual storage of valuable items. Kids love it! 
My design is based on the excellent creation of pasutx, which is also available on Thingiverse. My goal was to create a Cryptex that did not require any separate parts, paper or gluing. It can be easily modified to make it more secure by adding additional "deception" stops on the Outer Tube.
This Cryptex was created for a friend's birthday so it unlocks when the wheels are aligned as DEC14.
I suggest printing the Inner Tube and Outer Tube in separate colors if that capability is available to you. It looks great when the combination is dialed in and the two tubes are separated.
IMPORTANT NOTE: Due to the integrated design of the embossed lettering on the wheels and one piece stops on the tubes, this design will likely only print on a printer that includes support material. I printed this Cryptex on a Dimension BST with tolerances of .01 and all parts are appropriately tight, but operate smoothly. If anyone has suggestions that will allow the design to print without support material, I'm willing to give it a try.
I will upload a video of the working Cryptex on YouTube.

The Cryptex is very easy to assemble.
1) Put treasure or documents in Inner Tube.
2) Slip each wheel onto Outer Tube in the order DEC14. Each letter/number is designated by its position adjacent to the wheel slot.
3) Rotate each wheel 1/2 turn so that wheel slot is lined up with Outer Tube slot.
4) Slip Inner Tube into Outer Tube so that it slips past all five wheels.
5) Rotate wheels to random position which locks Inner Tube into Outer Tube.
6) The contents are now locked inside the Cryptex.

title: Radiator and pump mount for water cooling system
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
As more people realize the advantages of enclosing and heating their build chambers (especially for ABS printing), I believe that water cooling is going to be increasingly utilized in their builds. Extruders and stepper motors are going to need much more effective cooling.  
This bracket was designed to mount a common 120mm radiator fan combo, plus a common brushless cooling pump. Both of these items are available on eBay for under $20 each. You can also buy little aluminum CPU cooling blocks for about $3 each that are a perfect fit for cooling NEMA 17 steppers.  
Extruder cooling solutions will vary with extruder type. I am manufacturing a custom part out of aluminum for my DaVinci 1.0, but there are other designs already out there for E3D and similar hotends.  
Silicone tubing is much more flexible than vinyl, and is vastly superior in applications where the cooled part is moving (such as an extruder).

Mounting ears provided to mount to the back or side of your printer. Drill out holes as required for your mounting screws.
You will need qty 4 M3 sockethead capscrews to mount the radiator to the bracket. Minimum length 25mm, recommend 30mm length.
Use self tapping screws to mount the pump on top.

should not work, one of the TR10x2 nuts must be rotated 60 ° (ie spindle unscrew the back, pull TR10x2 nut from the holder and turned TR10x2 nut by 60 ° reinsert into the holder, screw spindle again (repeated up to 4 times) until it fits.
one 1mm tick alu washer (K8200 Z-axis part) can you using in the holder, see photo

title: Automatic Herb- or Flowerpot. Self-watering, led-lighted water-level indication and greenhous in one piece

description.text:
If you want fresh Herbs or flowers in you kitchen but don't have the green thumb, not enough light or just not the time than this is the solution ;) With this pot you can easily grow your herbs starting with seeds or already grown plants.
You don't have to water it very often, just add a cord to the pot (see instructions for details) and water will get from the saucer to the soil in your pot (works with cavity).
The water-level indicator will show you when its time to refill water in the saucer.
With the atached led light (common flexible usb light for laptop, e.g. from the big sweedish furniture shop) you don't need a window or natural light. Just add a timer to your USB-power supply an you have your own little sun. And if you forgot the candles for your romantic dinner, than you probably could sell this as a verry individual lamp ;) If you wan't to start with seeds, than just fill soil in the pot, put your seeds in it in and transform the pot into a mini-greenhaus with one or two layers of cling film and the cling film holder. If you like to give it your personal touch, print the" water level indicator deco" it countains a square 2x2mm to insert a small deco like the elephant or flower, i already uploaded. Just make sure thet its not to heavy.
If you dont want to use a light, than print the pot without the clip (plantpot_plain)

-printed with 15%infill
-2 solid layers bottom and top (make 3 for the saucer if you have problems with watertight printing)
-0.3mm layerhight -first time printed in pla with support, but design should print without
-print the water-level indicator without invill If you want the best result for the water-level indicator use abs for the level indicater due to its lower density und thus weight Use a wire to get the cord trough the bottom of the pot like shown in the picture. Make a short bend at the front to get it through, then hang in your cord, close the wire an pull it back. The holder for the led light fits tight. Start from one side and be gentle. Use a file or sandpaper if you don't get it snapping in. There are thre versions of the pot, Plantpot_led is for smaller plants, Plantpot_led2 for taller plants, the clip is near the upper side of the pot and alows you to put the led-light higher.
If you don't want to use a led light, than take Plantpot_plain, it's without the clip. To turn your pot in a greenhaus, simply take cling film, one or two layers, depending of its thickness place it over the pot, push the cling film holder over it and cut the excess cling film. If you wan't to add some deco, print "level indicator_deco", it contains a square 2x2mm wehre you can insert your own personal deco, name of the herbs or something else. I added two peices, a flower and elephant to get an idear how it works. Happy growing!

description.text: I love my new extruder on my SteelBug (https://solar1.net/drupal/Steel_Bug). But I have dozens of 3mm filament in various colors. This machine was built to convert (re-extrude) my 3mm fil to a 1.75mm fil. The bottom spool in this picture is an existing roll and was just placed there for demo purposes.

This was made from 1" square steel tubing from the hardware store. this could easily be constructed with aluminium extrusion but steel tubing is cheap, and I weld. The extruder is mounted on 1/4" steel plate welded to the tubing. The extruder is from an old printer and is controled by some old Thingomatic electronics. Basically set you temp based on abs/PLA in replicatorG and manually extrude for a long time. TODO::
My receiving spool may need a stepper driver to wind up the output. That will have to be for a future date. For now I just babysit the machine.

title: DailyEarring#59 Snail
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
(More DailyEarrings & prologue @ thingiverse.com/thing:7120 ) AE wanted a little snail, so here it is!
I just used the great Helix plugin for Sketchup, and drew some segment lines and extruded it manualy.
The snail is a 2D shape extruded with the round corners plugin.
The model is a bit sloppy but it was allready late, so have fun cleaning it :-) Prints fine on the UP+ (0.2mm/fine/30Â°) even the small detail version. Side-Note: I also printed http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7204 and uploaded a few images.

Note: Due to the import/export scales when I fixed the inverted parts, the object is too large to print. Scale by factor 0.03937 (in->mm). For UP users: Print standing and facing the front of the printer so it is easier to get out of the support material. Take care not to damage the thin ring.
Due to the sloppy, non-manifold shapes, there is some minor error in printing, but it can be cleaned with tweezers etc.

comments.text: I discover now that there has been an unfulfilled need in my life for a "rout" of snails.  Now that need has been realized...thanks to you!

author: OogiMe

description.text:
Prepare to lose some fingertips with this delightful kitchen gadget! Simply download, print and get chopping. Done making a mess? Go ahead and toss the whole thing in the dishwasher!  I added an integrated cutting board base that the whole assembly sits on.  Be sure to check each parts orientation before printing.  
Each part is designed to print well with only a minimum of support material. Comes with 3 blade designs: a plastic serrated, single razor, and double razor blade. I prefer the single razor- I find it works best. I included a plastic serrated blade for the kids. Blade mounts are simple push on/pull off. Chops a mean omelet :)   
Please be careful with the razor blades!!

I added some rubber adhesive pads to the bottom for a solid grip on the counter-top.  
Stainless Razor Blade part is optional, and must be assembled incredibly carefully. I recommend gripping razors with pliers and wearing work gloves.  
I have included a PDF with a workflow map and schematic of all the major parts, including their relationship to one another.  
I printed the Bevel Gears with a 0.2 mm layer height, but the larger Base, Housing, Chopping Bowl, and Lid with 0.3 mm. The cutting board should be printing with a fairly high density and large number of solid top layers for durability. A 20% - 50% infill on the rest should be adequate. Should take less than a day to print everything.   
I printed mine in ABS at 245C with 80C bed, and permanently fixed the drive shaft bushing to the housing with acetone.   
I designed each part with pretty tight tolerances, and tried to make each part fit well directly off the build plate, but a little hand filing may be necessary.to get the desired fit. I used chapstick as gear lube. Smells like cherries.

Salt is very important for making delicious food, but you cant eat too much. This container can give you a certain amount of salt when you put the spoon under the hole. There are two magnets in the container
and spoon, and their magnet pole are opposite, like N and N or S and S. When these two magnets get close, the plug will be pull back, the lower hole will be open, and the higher hole will be close. When you take the spoon away, the plug will get back to bottom by the gravity.
This model use the magnet 4mm*1.5mm, you can change the stl file if you have different size magnets. Then you stick the upper part and the lower part, don't forget put the plug in. At last you should find a bottle that fit
the machine size.

title: XuGong mount plate for brushless gimbal and FPV camera

description.text:
This is one of the custom parts that I designed for the ImmersionRC XuGong quadcopter frame. It originally came with a servo driven gimbal, this front mount plate makes it possible to easily screw on a brushless gimbal (the motor holes are in the standard 16mm and 19mm spacings).
Additionally, an FPV board camera can me mounted to this plate using a few bolts or zipties. The placing on the side makes sure the GoPro doesn't block the image. I added two versions of the plate, one with a large hole which makes access to the internals easier. The gimbal shown in the pictures is the Open Brushless Gimbal by turbi, found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:110731

A working key for the handcuffs used by Dutch and German police. Tested, works perfectly. This is a re-do of Ray's key, but I've used a real key as reference, so it's now much more accurate. Be careful about print quality. Make sure the key is as sturdy as you can make it, because you don't want it breaking off inside a handcuff.

Again: it's important that you print this as sturdy as possible, to prevent it breaking off inside a handcuff. Print it lying down. Use support material. Make it as solid as you can. You can even play around with your slicer's fudge setting to make it more densely packed (in Cura this means lowering the packing density, in other slicers try the filament diameter). Using small layer heights (e.g. 0.1mm) also helps to make it more sturdy. So, to recap:
  • Support material
  • Low layers
  • High fill
  • Really high fill
  • Print laying down

I didn't see any all in one arcade stick Raspberry Pi project plans out there that were free and/or well documented -- so I designed my own. This uses a Raspberry Pi and iPac2 keyboard emulator, so it can function as an all in one console - or just a joystick, depending on how you'd like to use it. The top and bottom are laser cut plexi, the side supports are 3D printed. See the instructions for more detailed information. The cost for everything was about $150. See here for parts list and ordering links from various sites: http://tinyurl.com/piarcadestick

The top and bottom plexiglass parts were designed in Illustrator, based on button layouts for the Sega Astro City cabinets (player one), which are very comfortable. Big up slagcoin, as that site has everything you'd ever want to know about joysticks: http://slagcoin.com/joystick.html The 3D printable side supports were designed in Tinkercad online. They are 3 inches high, but that height could be adjusted if you want something low profile. For me, it's a comfortable fit and allows easy access the the Pi and iPac. There aren't mounting holes on the bottom plexi, as I used Scotch fasteners (think plastic velcro) to attach them. See the parts list for more detail on that. I used machine screws because the tops are rounded and feel more comfortable. The ones around the joystick don't bother me at all, even after playing a while. Finally, see the parts list for the rubber bumpers. It's a nice touch on the bottom and it keeps the screws of the table and your joystick in place firmly on a table.

title: Suzuki DL1000 Windscreen Angle Adjuster Bushing/Spacer

description.text: If you own one of these bikes with a stock or aftermarket windscreen mounted to the stock windscreen mount you may notice some helmet buffeting. For me the buffeting is severe enough my vision blurs. All that I needed was to decrease the angle of the windscreen, and these small spacers eliminated all buffeting, at least for me. Buffeting depends on rider height, seat position, windscreen, etc so these may not work for you. I found these to be a much less expensive option to a Madstad or similar bracket that I'd end up setting and never moving as I did with my last windscreen of 10 years. My DL is a 2005 model, the windscreen is a vstream. This is a very simple object. The Sketchup file is included. 50mm bolts, metal washers, and thick rubber washers from Lowes are used to secure the lower section. The bracket cannot be used in the lowest position as the fairing blocks the lower mount from extending forward, but you can still use the top 3 bracket positions. The new position didn't allow me to use my steering lock so I got a pair of mirror extenders from adventuretech.biz, these work great and give me better visibility to the rear.

Printed with:
0.3mm resolution
50% density
Thick shells

description.text:
Now you can make your own Sugar Shaker.
This design combines 3D printing and recycling.
Please, go to the Instructions tab for more info.
https://youtu.be/xj1CZx2-xPw

First of all you have to print one copy of the three files “Pipe”, “Pipe nut” and “Stencil”.
Once you have finished with the printing process (should take you less than a couple of hours) you are ready for the assembly process.
You have to find a used jar (I choose a baby’s food jar, but it’s your choice) of about 10 cm (4 in) height. Using the printed stencil draw a square and cut it off with the help of a sharp knife or a cutter.
Now it’s time to make it look great. I have painted the lid using spray paint, it’s easy, clean and fast.
When the paint is fully dry, you can proceed to attach the nut trough the lid’s hole and screw the pipe onto it.
Prepare your favorite beverage and adjust the height of the pipe to reach your sweetness level ;) Do you like it? Did you make one? Can you improve the design? All feedback will be appreciated. You can use the comments section. Thanks!!

comments.text:
I did a similar design but with the difference of the holding nut.
Instead of a single squared nut, I used 2 nuts that one goes in the inside and the other on the outside of the lid.
When the nuts are tight to the pipe, they are compressed against the lid holding everything in place.
I felt it was easier to make a careless round hole rather than a perfect square.

Pi day came and went this year, and I created this just in time.
Prints fine with Cura. Created originally in sketchup, and then saved out as stl from Cura. I scaled it 3x and saved it out, so I think this will print about 23mm wide, as is, but verify of course.
Pictures in black are abs, looks better in person than in photo. Gray PLA looked great also, as would other colors. PLA prints with less hassle on my Prusa. Ignore the stray triangles in the thingiview, it prints great, nothing needs to be cut away (cura 15.02.1).
Pi is approximately 3.1415
Wikipedia entry for Pi: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pi
Pi day: http://www.piday.org/

I basically inserted the character pi into a text editor. Then I copied that text to clipboard. In Sketchup, I used the 3d text tool, and pasted the text from clipboard into the tool. I gave height 10 and the field next to Extrude to 2.
At this point I tried to print it as an .obj imported to Cura, but it did not print a top or bottom face. The missing step was to explode the text entity. Once I exploded the text entity inside sketchup, I saved it as .obj.
Cura imported the .obj file ( I rotated it face up ) and printed it perfect even though some stray triangles showed on the top and bottom in Cura.

description.text:
Sugar, spice and herb dispensers that, when squeezed, release either a pinch or a dash (1/16 or 1/8 of a teaspoon). All parts are printed and snap together easily. The parts can be printed in a variety of colour combinations, to easily identify the seasoning you want to use.  
Depending on the seasoning you are putting in or your cooking style, choose between the pinch or dash version; e.g. you may want to use the pinch for salt and the dash for basil.  
The stands are designed to sit on the counter or be attached to your wall/splash-back, with screws or strong sticky pads. The stands clips easily  together, so you can decide how many you want in your set.

Printing
Use the print screen photo as a reference for how to place everything on the platform. The spring needs to sit on one of its sides; when imported the spring will sit like an arch, rotate it 80% on the Y axis and then put in on the platform. The only part that needs support is the Stand. Assembly
First clip Case B to the Core, then put the 2 springs in Case A and slide the Core in all the way (as shown in the assembly photo). Filling
Pressing gently on the top and bottom of Case B will allow easy removal of the core. Hold a finger or thumb over the hole on the bottom while filling from the top. Use either a folded piece of paper or the funnel provided to fill the Core. While still holding the bottom hole, slide the core back into the case. Troubleshooting
If the Core is getting stuck when depressed with 2 springs, add a 3rd

description.text: Multiple line key chain or plate. Crossed out or not. This thing is multicolor by only changing the filament during printing, no dual extrusion is necessary. Please read the instructions. Of cause you can also print it monochrome. Simply open it in Customizer and enter your own text.

Layer height: 0.25
Infill: 100% !!! In customizer always set the output levels to a multiple of your layer height. I used Cura with the standard "Pause at Height" Plugin. So color change is really easy and exact, at least on Prusa i3 and similar printers. For the settings I have used, please refer the screenshot in the gallery. The printer pauses on the correct layer for color change. After changing the color you have to press a button on the printer. Another methode is shown by EtienneDusablon here.

description.text:
This is a basic pair of brackets to hold a shower curtain pole or similar,could be used to hold a clothes rail but I would be careful the amount of load put on printed bracket.
As they are made for a shower curtain there will be little weight on them.
They measure 46mm x 49mm and 20mm thick.
The bracket will take up to a 26mm diameter rod, being round a smaller rod will still sit nice in the bottom
The screw holes are 5mm and countersunk up to 8mm head.
They do what I want and if any one else finds them helpful thats a bonus.

I printed two sets as seen in the pictures.
printed in white and natural ABS at 0.4 layer for speed and 60% fill with 4 solid layers.
Came out as I hoped, just run a drill down the holes to clean them up.

author: StickNinja

description.text:
TL;DR : Recycle your Nespresso capsules. Easily, safely, hassle and mess free. Quick guide on how to use it:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yUxY0kESfBE
(The unit featured is a prototype. Uploaded version have size adjusted propelly). Please see instructions with the attached pictures on how to make it.

Using the single serve machine is convenient: pop a capsule, push and you're served.
But it does raise an important issue: how to recycle them? Nespresso do provide a recycling service but you have to stock the used pods and get to one of their salepoint or collect point... Problem for me is that I go to their store only twice a year... I won't stock 350 used pods in my home for that. So I needed a solution. Usual home recycling circuit doesn't allow throwing those pods has recyclable, you have to dump them in the normal garbage because of the used coffee inside that cannot be taken out in an automated process (in fact they can but they have to upgrade their lines). There's one or two device that exist where you litterally crush the pods to get the coffee out. A major issue with these is that it's not clean at all. There's still a lot of coffee left over. Plus the fact that you have to buy it... Another method is to do it by hand. Meaning you need a knife to cut the aluminum sheet (with all the risk involved playing with a knife...) and carve the interior yourself. Risky and time consuming... With this "must have" accessories for your Nespresso machine, you're covered.

It's a two parts design with a container to keep it stored and clean for the next batch of pods.
  • Top cover to keep the dust away.
  • Middle part is used to cut the thin aluminum sheet that seal the pods.
  • Extractor is to take out ALL the coffee from the pod in ONE single sweep.
  • The bottom case that hold everything stored.
    • As you precut the aluminum sheet, it ensure that you have the widest opening for the next step and it allow you to keep the capsule shape intact for possible future creative use (some people even put coffee back in after washing it).
    Not only it's MUCH easier but it's also the safest method. You don't have to use a knife, small bit of cutter blade are embedded inside the part and are only a millimeter out from the surface. The extractor is exactly shaped like the pod so simply insert it, twist and everything will get out. If you're lazy, you can use only this tool and not precut the aluminum cover but you won't get the best result.
    Prefer doing it on dry coffee (first one in video) as wet is a bit sticky. Now you can reuse your coffee ground as fertilizer for your plant (or many other reuse) and throw the aluminum to the recyclable. This is simply the best design available for that purpose. Easy. Fast. Safe. I know that Keurig is the king in USA/Canada but it's not available outside and in the rest of the world, Nespresso have the most market part.
Some model are not there, you can find more here: https://www.cgtrader.com/M600

Required buildplate: 50x50x75
Originally it was bigger with a collecting tray but I wanted my design to fit 99.99% of the 3D printer available on the market so everyone can make it. No support at all.
I designed it especially this way. No wast of plastic and printing is a breeze. Part needed to complete the build:
  • 4 small piece of a break away 9mm cutter blade (used blade is plenty fine, you don't need a sharp edge)
    • Instructions:
    Print everything. Take the middle piece and the blocker: push them together.
    There's four small notch in the middle part to insert theses pieces of blade.
    Put them all in the same direction (clockwise or anti if you're comfortable with it).
    Push (not with your finger...) all the way inside until it stop or there's about a millimeter out. Small plier is ideal. That's it. You're done. The small blade should be held snug enough and will rise up just about right to slice through the aluminum sheet.

description.text:
Have you ever saw a pot of coffee, but don't know when it was made? You pour a cup, put your cream or sugar or whatever it is that you desire into it, and then only realize that it's burnt after the first sip? We all have.  
BUT NOT ANYMORE  
This spoon rest has built in slides. As long as you remember to set when you made the coffee, you'll never have to worry about burnt nasty coffee and a wasted effort again!

I made this for standard 3d printing filament rolls with 55mm opening
the dimensions are aprox. 55mm round(main) x 65mm tall and the center hole is 10mm. This helps the filament roll spin freely during printing and puts less stress on your extruder when extruding filament. I have test printed this and it works great! ENJOY!
I printed this in abs @5% infill, 1.2mm in/out and 1mm bottom and top. With 5% infill the part is more than strong enough to hold any roll that will fit.

title: The Kup Twist- Spiral K-cup holder

description.text: ​Stylish K cup holder with a spiral design! This K cup holder is a work of art and is sure to impress anyone that sees it. Print as many center pieces as you want to make it as tall as you want. All parts snap tightly together when printed from my printer. I tried to make the tolerances on the clips not too tight because I wanted it to work with any printer. If the parts are too loose then a little dab of glue works great! The holder spins very nicely when put on the stand. All supports are built in, just snap them off when done printing. Then all you need to do is assemble your Kup Twist holder then enjoy a nice cup of coffee while admiring your new K cup holder!!
All pieces snap together, and also use glue if fitment it too lose for you. Refer to the pictures to see how thy come together.

comments.text: What infill are you using? I printed this all out with 40% and keep breaking the tabs.. I Keep breaking them.

comments.text: Scratch that.. For anyone wondering, it would be a good idea to fill the top portion of the piece part 100% if your splicer has the option. Those clips are pretty hollow at 40% infill.

comments.text: Glad you figured it out, you may want to increase your wall thickness if those parts keep breaking on you, then you may not need to do 100% infill. Glad that you like the design!

comments.text: Yeah.. They all keep breaking. Went to put on the top and any movement breaks the other tabs. If I make it again, I'll try the wall thickness. I'm probably going to print things with heavy use with more infill.. It doesn't cost that much more. Just increases print time.

title: Prusa i3 Z Axis Stabilizer for board mount

description.text:
This is a z axis stabilizer for my Replikeo Prusa i3 Rework. I found that the z axis was bouncing during prints. This makes it rock solid. It bolts on to the top using the same bolts that hold on the z axis smooth rod supports. The bottom screws into the board that the printer is mounted on.   
Requires one 5/16" x 36" rod cut in half, 8 nuts, and 4 screws.
